Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Documentation of Tornado Track of Mayflower Tornado in Hilly Terrain

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tornados are severe storms that occur randomly. In the contiguous United States close to 1,000 tornadoes occur each year. Since the storms are short lived and cover relatively small areas, it has not been possible to record wind speeds in tornadoes with instruments near the ground. Documentation of damage and pattern of tree-fall give indication of winds in tornadoes. The intensity of a tornado is judged by the National Weather Service by assigning a number on the EF scale, which is based on building damage. More knowledge is needed about winds in tornadoes near ground so the buildings and structures can be designed to resist these storms. The EF4 intensity tornado that occurred in Arkansas can provide data on near ground winds as the tornado tracked over hilly terrain.

This Rapid Research Grant (RAPID) project plans to assemble damage data of buildings and trees in the field along the 41 mile long track of the tornado that occurred on April 27, 2014 in hilly terrain in Arkansas. The hypothesis is that tornado wind speed at ground level increases going uphill and decreases on downhill side as the tornado interacts with hilly terrain. Since it has not been possible to measure wind speeds in tornadoes at ground level with instruments, damage to buildings and trees provide a good indication of winds. The field data will include photographs taken from air as well as from ground, Google Earth signature of the terrain, radar data, and other data that may be available from media. The gathered data will be organized along with preliminary analysis for initial verification of the hypothesis. The data will be useful to researchers who are pursuing computational simulation of tornado vortex as well as to investigators who are pursuing physical simulation in wind tunnel.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tornados are damaging wind storms that annually cause 122 deaths and $5.5 billion in property damage in the United States. Researchers such as the Doppler on Wheels team have greatly increased understanding of tornadic wind structure. Most of these studies focus on tornados in “tornado alley”, which is located in the flat, central region of the United States. The influence complex, hilly topography on tornados’ ground level path and damage intensity has received little study. The EF4 tornado in the Mayflower, AR area on April 27, 2014 provided a unique opportunity to document the influence of hilly terrain on the ground-level path and damage intensity of a tornado.

The present investigation consisted of documentation of the tornado’s damage track through hilly terrain by in-field investigation as well as by integrating aerial- and satellite photographs of damage from numerous sources. Numerous damage sights are identified where the tornado-vortex travels over both flat and hilly terrain. The tornado’s damage intensity is much greater (EF3 – 4) when it is travelling over flat terrain than when it travels in hilly terrain (EF0 – EF2). This is because the hilly terrain disrupts the circulating tornado-vortex wind field. Furthermore, the ground-level path of the tornado is influenced by the presence of hills and ridgelines. Several sights distinctly show the tornado traveling along ridgelines until encountering and passing through gaps rather than travelling directly over the ridgeline.

These findings are significant firstly because they increase the present knowledge base on the behavior of tornados. More importantly, they may be applied when planning the location of a new structure. Finally, they may improve forecasting of tornado paths once the tornado has touched down, thereby providing increased warning to areas in the damage path.

 The research performed herein has been used to train four graduate students and one undergraduate student. The findings of the study have been disseminated through three technical presentations, one conference paper, and two journal papers as well as through a final report available at the website: http://compmech.cveg.uark.edu/Mayflower-2014/Mayflower%20Tornado%20Final%20Report.pdf
